1. Properties of shapes

Types of quadrilaterals

Given the following diagram:

Select the most specific name for the figure from choices in the list below.

Answer: The shape is a .
STEP: Select the most specific name for the shape shown
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This polygon has four sides, so it is a quadrilateral. In fact, we were given that two pairs of adjacent sides are equal.

A kite is a quadrilateral with two pairs of adjacent sides equal.

A rhombus is a quadrilateral with two pairs of opposite sides parallel and adjacent sides equal.

Types of quadrilaterals

Given the following diagram:

Select the most specific name for the figure from choices in the list below.

Answer: The shape is a .
STEP: Select the most specific name for the shape shown
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

A rectangle is a quadrilateral with two pairs of opposite sides parallel and all corners 90°90°.

So, this quadrilateral is a rectangle.

2. The theorem of Pythagoras

Apply Pythagoras

Determine the value of tt.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: t=t= units
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.005))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

The theorem of Pythagoras gives a relationship between the three sides in a triangle. What is the relationship?

STEP: Use the theorem of Pythagoras to find tt
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

The theorem of Pythagoras tells us that:

In a right-angled triangle, the sum of the squares of the two short sides is equal to the square of the hypotenuse.

The hypotenuse is the side opposite the right angle.

DF2∴42∴16∴16−9∴7∴t2=DE2+EF2(Pythagoras)=t2+32=t2+9=t2+9−9=t2=7DF2=DE2+EF2(Pythagoras)∴42=t2+32∴16=t2+9∴16−9=t2+9−9∴7=t2∴t2=7

The equation t2=7t2=7 has two solutions: 7‾√7 or −7‾√−7. However, tt is always positive because it is a length. So, we discard the negative solution. We must use our calculator to determine the positive square root of 77.

t∴t∴t=7‾√=2,64575...=2,65t=7∴t=2,64575...∴t=2,65

Therefore tt is 2,65 units2,65 units.

NOTE: Pythagoras was a man who lived in Greece 2500 years ago. Whenever we use his theorem, we have to write Pythagoras as our reason. It is our way of thanking him for proving this very important fact about triangles.

A ladder is 25 metres25 metres long. The bottom of the ladder is placed on the ground 15 metres15 metres away from a wall. The ladder is leaned against the wall and it just touches the top. How high is the wall?

Answer: The wall is metresmetres high.
numeric

STEP: Draw a diagram and label everything you know

The ladder is 25 metres25 metres long. The distance from the wall to the base of the ladder is 15 metres15 metres.

The ladder is the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle. Let the height of the wall be xx.

STEP: Use the theorem of Pythagoras to calculate the height of the wall
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]
(25)2625625−225400x2xxx=(15)2+x2(Pythagoras)=225+x2=225+x2−225=x2=400=±400‾‾‾‾√=±20=20(25)2=(15)2+x2(Pythagoras)625=225+x2625−225=225+x2−225400=x2x2=400x=±400x=±20x=20
NOTE: When dealing with lengths, the answer cannot be negative. So we must throw away the negative answer.

Longest straight line

A rectangular piece of paper is 32 cm32 cm long and 23 cm23 cm wide.

What is the length of the longest straight line that can be drawn across this piece of paper?

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: Longest line = cmcm
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.005))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

There is always one way to draw the longest line across a rectangle. Use your ruler and a piece of paper to figure out what this is.

STEP: Figure out how to draw the longest line
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

At first, you might think that the length of the paper is the longest straight line.

However, you will notice that as you move the ruler up the opposite side of the page, the line gets longer.

If we keep moving the endpoint of the line up, the line gets longer and longer until we get to the diagonal. If we keep going on, the line gets shorter again. So, the diagonal is the longest possible straight line.

STEP: Calculate the length of the diagonal
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

The diagonal is the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle, so we can use the theorem of Pythagoras. Let the length of the diagonal be dd.

d2∴d2∴d∴d=(32)2+(23)2(Pythagoras)=1553=1553‾‾‾‾‾√=39,40812...≈39,41 cmd2=(32)2+(23)2(Pythagoras)∴d2=1553∴d=1553∴d=39,40812...≈39,41 cm

Therefore, the length of the longest straight line that can be drawn across this piece of paper is 39,41 cm39,41 cm.

NOTE: You must write "Pythagoras" as your reason to explain your thinking.
Submit your answer as:

Calculate the length of the hypotenuse

The diagram below shows a right-angled triangle.

Use the theorem of Pythagoras to calculate the length of the hypotenuse.

Answer: The length of the hypotenuse is unitsunits.
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

The theorem of Pythagoras states:

a2+b2=c2a2+b2=c2
.

In this formula, cc represents the hypotenuse. You need to substitute the other sides of the triangle into the formula for aa and bb. Then solve for cc.

STEP: Identify the hypotenuse and substitute into the theorem of Pythagoras
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We have a right-angled triangle, and we know two of the side lengths. We need to find the length of the third side. We can use the theorem of Pythagoras to solve this question because it connects all three sides of any right-angled triangle. The theorem states:

a2+b2=c2a2+b2=c2

where:

  • cc is the hypotenuse of the triangle.
  • aa and bb are the other two sides of the triangle.

Whenever we use the theorem of Pythagoras, we must identify the hypotenuse of the triangle. The hypotenuse is always the side opposite from the right angle.

In this question, we need to find the hypotenuse, cc. We can substitute the other two sides in for aa and bb.

a2+b2(6)2+(8)2=c2(Pythagoras)=c2a2+b2=c2(Pythagoras)(6)2+(8)2=c2
NOTE: It does not matter which number we substitute in for aa and which for bb. The side that matters is the hypotenuse. So we could substitute the lengths in the other way, and we will still get the correct answer:
a2+b2(8)2+(6)2=c2=c2a2+b2=c2(8)2+(6)2=c2
STEP: Solve for cc
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

Now we can solve the equation for the value of cc. First evaluate the left side of the equation.

(6)2+(8)236+64100=c2=c2=c2(6)2+(8)2=c236+64=c2100=c2

Now we must take the square root of both sides of the equation to remove the exponent on cc. When we do this, we must remember to bring in a ±± symbol. This is because if 100=c2100=c2, there are two numbers which can make 100100 when we square them: one positive number and one negative number.

100±100‾‾‾‾√±10=c2=c=c100=c2±100=c±10=c

This means:

c=10orc=−10c=10orc=−10
STEP: Find the final answer
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

We get two different answers because when you square either 1010 or −10−10 you get 100100. But remember that we are calculating a length. And so the answer cannot be negative (a length must be positive). That means we must throw away the negative answer, leaving c=10c=10.

TIP: The hypotenuse is always the longest side of a right-angled triangle. Check your answer to make sure it is larger than the other two sides of the triangle.

The length of the hypotenuse is 1010 units.

Calculating diagonals

The side of a square is 4 cm4 cm long.

What is the length of the diagonal of the square? Give a reason for your answer.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: Diagonal == cmcm
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.005))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Draw a diagram to represent the scenario. Remember, a diagonal goes from one corner to the opposite corner, cutting the quadrilateral into two triangles.

STEP: Draw a diagram
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

The diagonal goes from one corner of the square to the other corner. Since this is a square, we also know that the corner angles are all equal to 90°90°.

Since this is a square we know that all the sides will be equal to 4 cm4 cm.

We have now formed two right-angled triangles. So, we can use the theorem of Pythagoras to calculate the length of the diagonal.

STEP: Apply the theorem of Pythagoras
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Let the diagonal be dd.

∴∴∴d2d2dd=42+42(Pythagoras)=32=32‾‾‾√=5,6568...≈5,66 cmd2=42+42(Pythagoras)∴d2=32∴d=32∴d=5,6568...≈5,66 cm

Therefore, the diagonal is 5,66 cm5,66 cm in length.

NOTE: The equation d2=32d2=32 has two solutions: 5,665,66 or −5,66−5,66. But, dd is always positive because it is a length. So, we ignore the negative solution.

Theorem of Pythagoras

The diagram shows the right-angled triangle UVWUVW. Two of the sides have known lengths: UV=6UV=6 and VW=8VW=8. The third side is labelled xx.

  1. What is the name of the side labelled xx?
  2. Determine the value of xx.
Answer:
  1. The name of the side labelled xx is
  2. x=x= unitsunits.
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

The theorem of Pythagoras states that c2=a2+b2c2=a2+b2. You need to write this equation using the sides of this triangle: 6,8,6,8, and xx.

STEP: Find the name of the missing side
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

The first part of this question asks us to name the side of the triangle labelled xx. The side is named according to its endpoints, which are UU and WW. So we can refer to the side as either UWUW or WUWU.

The correct choice from the list is UW.

STEP: Use the theorem of Pythagoras to calculate the value of xx
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

We can answer this question using the theorem of Pythagoras because the triangle is a right-angled triangle. To use the theorem of Pythagoras we must identify which side of the triangle is the hypotenuse. The hypotenuse is the side of the triangle across from the right angle.

In this case we need to find the length of the hypotenuse. So,

x2x2x2xx=(6)2+(8)2(Pythagoras)=36+64=100=±100‾‾‾‾√=10x2=(6)2+(8)2(Pythagoras)x2=36+64x2=100x=±100x=10
NOTE: We can see that xx can be either −100‾‾‾‾√−100 or +100‾‾‾‾√+100. But since the answer is a length, it cannot be a negative number. So we throw out the negative answer and keep the positive one.

The correct answers are:

  1. The side labelled xx is UW.
  2. x=x= 10 units10 units.

Two step Pythagoras

In the diagram below, PS⊥QRPS⊥QR. Also, PQ=26unitsPQ=26units, QS=21unitsQS=21units, and PR=35unitsPR=35units.

Determine the length of RSRS.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: RS=RS= unitsunits
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.005))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

You have enough information to calculate a side in one of the triangles.

STEP: Calculate the length of PSPS
[−4 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

We do not have enough information to calculate RSRS straight away. We must first determine PSPS, then we will use this information to calculate RSRS.

NOTE: We were given that PS⊥QRPS⊥QR. This means that PŜ Q=90°PS^Q=90° and PŜ R=90°PS^R=90°.

ΔPQSΔPQS is a right-angled triangle, and we know the lengths of two sides in the triangle.

So, we can use the theorem of Pythagoras to determine the length of PSPS.

PS2+212=262(Pythagoras)PS2+212=262(Pythagoras)
∴PS2+441∴PS2+441−441∴PS2∴PS=676=676−441=235=235‾‾‾‾√units∴PS2+441=676∴PS2+441−441=676−441∴PS2=235∴PS=235units
TIP: You should store this number in your calculator (do not round off). Use this stored value in the next step. If you round off at this step, you might get a slightly different answer.
STEP: Calculate RSRS
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

Now that we know the length of PSPS, we have enough information to calculate RSRS.

RS2+(235‾‾‾‾√)2=352(Pythagoras)RS2+(235)2=352(Pythagoras)
NOTE: Squaring and taking the square root are inverse operations - they undo each other. So, when you calculate (235‾‾‾‾√)2(235)2, you just get 235235.
∴RS2+235∴RS2+235−235∴RS2∴RS∴RS∴RS=1225=1225−235=990=990‾‾‾‾√=31,46426...=31,46units∴RS2+235=1225∴RS2+235−235=1225−235∴RS2=990∴RS=990∴RS=31,46426...∴RS=31,46units
NOTE: In geometry it is very important to write down the all of the steps and reasons that explain your thinking.

Working backwards from the diagonal

The diagonal of a square is 4 m4 m.

What is the length of each side of the square? Give a reason for your answer.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: Each side == mm
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.005))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Draw a diagram to represent the scenario. Let the unknown side be xx.

STEP: Draw a diagram
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

The diagonal goes from one corner of the square to the other corner. Since this is a square, we also know that the corner angles are all equal to 90°90°.

We have now formed two right-angled triangles. So, we can use the theorem of Pythagoras to calculate the length of the sides.

STEP: Apply the theorem of Pythagoras
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Let a side of the square be xx. All of the sides of a square are the same length. So if we let one side be xx, then the other sides must also be xx.

∴∴∴∴∴x2+x22x22x22x2xx=(4)2(Pythagoras)=16=162=8=8‾√=2,8284...≈2,83 mx2+x2=(4)2(Pythagoras)∴2x2=16∴2x22=162∴x2=8∴x=8∴x=2,8284...≈2,83 m

Walking across a field

Chidi lives on the opposite side of a rectangular field from his school. He can either walk around the outside of the field, or straight across.

Yesterday Chidi walked around the outside of the field to get to school. He walked straight for 40 m40 m, then turned left and walked another 62 m62 m.

Today, he decides to walk straight across the field. How much shorter will his walk be today?

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to the nearest metre (m)metre (m).
Answer:

Chidi's walk will be mm shorter than yesterday.

one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.5))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

The route across the field forms a right-angled triangle. Which theorem allows you to calculate sides in a right-angled triangle?

STEP: Calculate the distance across the field
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

The field is a rectangle, and the route across the field forms a right-angled triangle.

We can use the theorem of Pythagoras to calculate the distance across the field. Let the distance be dd.

The theorem of Pythagoras and surds

Triangle QRSQRS is given with sides RS=1RS=1 and QR=1QR=1. Determine the length of the hypotenuse in surd form, without using a calculator.

INSTRUCTIONS:
  • You must write your answer in surd form (with a square root). To type a square root, use 'sqrt'. For example, if the answer is 3‾√3 you should type: sqrt(3)
  • Decimal answers will not be marked as correct.
Answer: The length of the hypotenuse is unitsunits.
expression
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Start by substituting the values 11 and 11 into the formula.

STEP: Substitute the values into the theorem of Pythagoras
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

We need to find the length of the hypotenuse for the triangle. We can use the theorem of Pythagoras because it is a right-angled triangle. As always, we must identify the hypotenuse of the triangle. The hypotenuse is always the side of the triangle across from the right angle, as shown here:

The variable cc represents the hypotenuse in the theorem of Pythagoras. So we can substitute the other sides of the triangle in for aa and bb.

a2+b2(1)2+(1)2=c2(Pythagoras)=c2a2+b2=c2(Pythagoras)(1)2+(1)2=c2
STEP: Solve for cc
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now we can solve the equation. First we need to evaluate the left side. Then we will have to square root both sides of the equation (that is how we will change c2c2 into cc).

(1)2+(1)21+1±2‾√=c2=c2=c(1)2+(1)2=c21+1=c2±2=c

The number inside of the root does not have any square factors. So to simplify any more is not possible. The question stated that the answer should be given as an exact value, so do not change this expression to a decimal value. That means we have two answers:

c=2‾√orc=−2‾√c=2orc=−2

We must throw away the negative answer because the answer we want is a length, so it cannot be negative. That leaves one answer, which is c=2‾√c=2.

TIP: We can check the answer by comparing it to the other sides of the triangle. The hypotenuse is always the longest side of a right-angled triangle. You can use your calculator to find that 2‾√≈1,412≈1,41. If this number is not larger than the other two sides, there is a mistake in the solution!

STEP: Use the theorem of Pythagoras to find tt
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

The theorem of Pythagoras tells us that:

In a right-angled triangle, the sum of the squares of the two short sides is equal to the square of the hypotenuse.

The hypotenuse is the side opposite the right angle.

PR2∴192∴361∴361−256∴105∴t2=PQ2+QR2(Pythagoras)=t2+162=t2+256=t2+256−256=t2=105PR2=PQ2+QR2(Pythagoras)∴192=t2+162∴361=t2+256∴361−256=t2+256−256∴105=t2∴t2=105

The equation t2=105t2=105 has two solutions: 105‾‾‾‾√105 or −105‾‾‾‾√−105. However, tt is always positive because it is a length. So, we discard the negative solution. We must use our calculator to determine the positive square root of 105105.

t∴t∴t=105‾‾‾‾√=10,24695...=10,25t=105∴t=10,24695...∴t=10,25

Therefore tt is 10,25 cm10,25 cm.

Longest straight line

A rectangular piece of paper is 35 cm35 cm long and 25 cm25 cm wide.

What is the length of the longest straight line that can be drawn across this piece of paper?

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: Longest line = cmcm
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.005))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

There is always one way to draw the longest line across a rectangle. Use your ruler and a piece of paper to figure out what this is.

STEP: Figure out how to draw the longest line
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

At first, you might think that the length of the paper is the longest straight line.

However, you will notice that as you move the ruler up the opposite side of the page, the line gets longer.

If we keep moving the endpoint of the line up, the line gets longer and longer until we get to the diagonal. If we keep going on, the line gets shorter again. So, the diagonal is the longest possible straight line.

STEP: Calculate the length of the diagonal
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

The diagonal is the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle, so we can use the theorem of Pythagoras. Let the length of the diagonal be dd.

d2∴d2∴d∴d=(35)2+(25)2(Pythagoras)=1850=1850‾‾‾‾‾√=43,01162...≈43,01 cmd2=(35)2+(25)2(Pythagoras)∴d2=1850∴d=1850∴d=43,01162...≈43,01 cm

Therefore, the length of the longest straight line that can be drawn across this piece of paper is 43,01 cm43,01 cm.

NOTE: You must write "Pythagoras" as your reason to explain your thinking.

Calculate the length of the hypotenuse

The diagram below shows a right-angled triangle.

Use the theorem of Pythagoras to calculate the length of the hypotenuse.

Answer: The length of the hypotenuse is unitsunits.
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

The theorem of Pythagoras states:

a2+b2=c2a2+b2=c2
.

In this formula, cc represents the hypotenuse. You need to substitute the other sides of the triangle into the formula for aa and bb. Then solve for cc.

STEP: Identify the hypotenuse and substitute into the theorem of Pythagoras
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We have a right-angled triangle, and we know two of the side lengths. We need to find the length of the third side. We can use the theorem of Pythagoras to solve this question because it connects all three sides of any right-angled triangle. The theorem states:

a2+b2=c2a2+b2=c2

where:

  • cc is the hypotenuse of the triangle.
  • aa and bb are the other two sides of the triangle.

Whenever we use the theorem of Pythagoras, we must identify the hypotenuse of the triangle. The hypotenuse is always the side opposite from the right angle.

In this question, we need to find the hypotenuse, cc. We can substitute the other two sides in for aa and bb.

a2+b2(5)2+(12)2=c2(Pythagoras)=c2a2+b2=c2(Pythagoras)(5)2+(12)2=c2
NOTE: It does not matter which number we substitute in for aa and which for bb. The side that matters is the hypotenuse. So we could substitute the lengths in the other way, and we will still get the correct answer:
a2+b2(12)2+(5)2=c2=c2a2+b2=c2(12)2+(5)2=c2
STEP: Solve for cc
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

Now we can solve the equation for the value of cc. First evaluate the left side of the equation.

(5)2+(12)225+144169=c2=c2=c2(5)2+(12)2=c225+144=c2169=c2

Now we must take the square root of both sides of the equation to remove the exponent on cc. When we do this, we must remember to bring in a ±± symbol. This is because if 169=c2169=c2, there are two numbers which can make 169169 when we square them: one positive number and one negative number.

169±169‾‾‾‾√±13=c2=c=c169=c2±169=c±13=c

This means:

c=13orc=−13c=13orc=−13
STEP: Find the final answer
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

We get two different answers because when you square either 1313 or −13−13 you get 169169. But remember that we are calculating a length. And so the answer cannot be negative (a length must be positive). That means we must throw away the negative answer, leaving c=13c=13.

TIP: The hypotenuse is always the longest side of a right-angled triangle. Check your answer to make sure it is larger than the other two sides of the triangle.

The length of the hypotenuse is 1313 units.

Calculating diagonals

The length of a rectangle is 10 cm10 cm, and the breadth is 8 cm8 cm.

What is the length of the diagonal of the rectangle? Give a reason for your answer.

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to two decimal places.
Answer: Diagonal == cmcm
one-of
type(numeric.abserror(0.005))
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

Draw a diagram to represent the scenario. Remember, a diagonal goes from one corner to the opposite corner, cutting the quadrilateral into two triangles.

STEP: Draw a diagram
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

The diagonal goes from one corner of the rectangle to the other corner. Since this is a rectangle, we also know that the corner angles are all equal to 90°90°.

We have now formed two right-angled triangles. So, we can use the theorem of Pythagoras to calculate the length of the diagonal.

STEP: Apply the theorem of Pythagoras
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

Let the diagonal be dd.

∴∴∴d2d2dd=102+82(Pythagoras)=164=164‾‾‾‾√=12,8062...≈12,81 cmd2=102+82(Pythagoras)∴d2=164∴d=164∴d=12,8062...≈12,81 cm

Therefore, the diagonal is 12,81 cm12,81 cm in length.

In a right-angled triangle, the sum of the squares of the two short sides is equal to the square of the hypotenuse.

The hypotenuse is the side opposite the right angle.

PQ2+QR292+12281+144225y2=PR2(Pythagoras)=y2=y2=y2=225PQ2+QR2=PR2(Pythagoras)92+122=y281+144=y2225=y2y2=225

Yesterday Lesedi walked around the outside of the field to get to school. She walked straight for 52 m52 m, then turned left and walked another 31 m31 m.

Today, she decides to walk straight across the field. How much shorter will her walk be today?

INSTRUCTION: Round your answer to the nearest metre (m)metre (m).
Answer:

Lesedi's walk will be mm shorter than yesterday.

=≈83−60,5422,4622 m83−60,54=22,46≈22 m

The variable cc represents the hypotenuse in the theorem of Pythagoras. So we can substitute the other sides of the triangle in for aa and bb.

a2+b2(4)2+(5)2=c2(Pythagoras)=c2a2+b2=c2(Pythagoras)(4)2+(5)2=c2

We must throw away the negative answer because the answer we want is a length, so it cannot be negative. That leaves one answer, which is c=41‾‾‾√c=41.

The hypotenuse is the special side, and it can never be swapped with the other sides.
STEP: Solve for cc
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now we can solve the equation. First we need to evaluate the left side. Then we will have to square root both sides of the equation (that is how we will change c2c2 into cc).

(3)2+(7)29+49±58‾‾‾√=c2=c2=c(3)2+(7)2=c29+49=c2±58=c

The number inside of the root does not have any square factors. So to simplify any more is not possible. The question stated that the answer should be given as an exact value, so do not change this expression to a decimal value. That means we have two answers:

c=58‾‾‾√orc=−58‾‾‾√c=58orc=−58

We must throw away the negative answer because the answer we want is a length, so it cannot be negative. That leaves one answer, which is c=58‾‾‾√c=58.

TIP: We can check the answer by comparing it to the other sides of the triangle. The hypotenuse is always the longest side of a right-angled triangle. You can use your calculator to find that 58‾‾‾√≈7,6258≈7,62. If this number is not larger than the other two sides, there is a mistake in the solution!

The length of the hypotenuse is 58‾‾‾√58 unitsunits.
